title: Is it true that there's no money in writing poetry? - Quora

response.answer_text: In my honest opinion I believe there is a lot of money in writing poetry; when you think of that type of literature, your mind almost instantaneously go to the traditional foundation of the art. -When there are various ways of poetry, it can be expressed musically, as a short story, a diary entry, even using the prose technique. It’s up to you how interesting you want to be; and usually when you’re telling a story that is misunderstood and hard to interpret in a way that it becomes so intriguing that - the literature itself, turns into many interpretations - is how you know you found yourself a winner! Not only is it your story - it brings that saying, “you had to be there, you can't make this up!” out in your craft of what your perspective was in whatever moment you experienced in your life. If that it is priceless to you, imagine how much you're worth to someone who’ll never understand? This was an interesting question no matter how simple it may have seen to the single-minded lol no shade just a joke! =) -Ki Wi

I hope it’s true that there’s no money in writing poetry: that means that my poetry is not so bad. Otherwise, with all the money being made by good poets, I must be really bad because I’m not getting it. If you want to see what’s not making money you can look at Back Door Poetry - Kindle edition by Douglas Gilbert. Literature & Fiction Kindle eBooks @ Amazon.com. or a really good failure to prosper: The Murder of Asperger's Last Poet: The Poetry Legacy - Kindle edition by Douglas Gilbert. Literature & Fiction Kindle eBooks @ Amazon.com. I’ve read poetry on the street, at open mikes in bars, I’ve given away books, I’ve donated books, and like a gambler I’ve spent more money than I’ve taken in. I’ve written tragic, happy, romantic, satiric, philosophical, frivolous, free-verse, unfree, under and over a tree, a moon, a sun, a puddle of blood. None is money.
